titleStmt.title: Isaac Israëls aan Jo van Gogh-Bonger. Londen, 21 september 1914.
Isaac Israëls to Jo van Gogh-Bonger. London, 21 September 1914.

publisher.name: Huygens Institute for the History and Culture of the Netherlands (KNAW)
Van Gogh Museum Amsterdam

div.p:
Certainly Vincent is very nice and I congratulate you upon your success with him. I hope to see him soon again and you too. If I could I should go at once to the Hague
or Paris. It will be soon in any case.

Many thanks for the second volume of the letters, it is very interesting lecture only how stupid it has really been to live in the same town with that man and not knowing him. It was certainly not
his fault however and I should probably not have understood him then. When you grow wise it is generally, too late.
Mevr. Wed. J. Cohen Gosschalk van Gogh

note.p: Briefhoofd: ‘21 september’. Poststempel: 21 september 1914. Sluitzegel: ‘Openend by censor’. Omwille van deze censor, die tijdens de Eerste Wereldoorlog post controleerde, schreef Israëls zijn brief in het Engels.
Letter headed ‘21 September’. Postmark: ’21 September 1914’. Seal: ‘Opened by censor’. For the sake of this censor, which checked post during the First World War, Israëls wrote his letter in English.

Jo’s zoon Vincent en Israëls hadden elkaar kort daarvoor in Londen getroffen. Isaac maakte toen een portret van hem: Isaac Israëls, Vincent Willem van Gogh in Hyde Park, Londen, 1914. Vincent, die in januari 1914 na zes jaar studeren zijn diploma werktuigkundig ingenieur had behaald, had een baan waarin hij voor een halfjaar bouwopdrachten in de Pyreneeën begeleidde.
Vincent van Gogh, Brieven aan zijn broeder (1914), deel 2.

Isaac Israëls en Vincent van Gogh hadden elkaar kunnen ontmoeten tussen 1881 en 1883, toen ze gelijktijdig in Den Haag woonden. In 1881 debuteerde Israëls in Den Haag op de tentoonstelling Kunstwerken van Levende Meesters met De repetitie van het signaal (De Mesdag Collectie, Den Haag), en in 1882 had hij op de Salon des Artistes Français in Parijs een eervolle vermelding gekregen voor Militaire Begrafenis (Kunstmuseum, Den Haag).
Jo’s son Vincent and Israëls had met in London shortly before. Isaac made a portrait of him then: Isaac Israëls, Vincent Willem van Gogh in Hyde Park, London, 1914.
Vincent, who had gained his degree as a mechanical engineer in January 1914 after six years of study, had a job in which he supervised construction projects in the Pyrenees.
Vincent van Gogh, Brieven aan zijn broeder (1914), volume 2.

Isaac Israëls and Vincent van Gogh could have met between 1881 and 1883, when they were living in The Hague at the same time. In 1881 Israëls made his first appearance in The Hague at the exhibition of works of living artists with Practising the Signal (the Mesdag Collection, The Hague), and in 1882 he had been awarded an honourable mention at the Salon des Artistes Français in Paris for Military Funeral (Kunstmuseum, The Hague).
